Researchers are researching the effectiveness of marijuana treatment known as "Marijuana Compound" in treating multiple health conditions in Western New York.
Other therapeutic modes have been used to treat osteoporosis, AIDS and other diseases, among other things. But in Western New York, the Treatment Aggregation effect is the most widely used.
Past research has shown that marijuana-based treatment for some conditions that the drug involves doesn't work. According to Wisconsin-based study author Carl Ames, this problem is due to the large number of patients with back pain or arthritis who claim marijuana can assist in their recovery.
Ames says that the brain's reaction to marijuana-based pain treatment is typically at the higher levels the user uses. Those with arthritis tend to have one problem but another.
Ames and his colleagues studied about 2000 patients of Ohio State University, about 40,000 of whom were adult men and used a standard procedure called state-approved pain monitors.
A patient who passed the state-approved pain monitor completed 4 1/2 milligrams of THC each day for another week and a placebo for one week.
The study's findings are presented by Ames as a model of how marijuana treatment works in Western New York. One can limit use to the patients' muscles that are already damaged but stay current with equipment and data, but "it's a lot of use," says Ames.
Ames also thinks the study demonstrates the potential of using a wide variety of antidepressant drugs, including antidepressant drugs including both naltrexone and Zocor. With medication, the patient is less likely to burn out or become irritable, so taking them both may help keep the dosage at a lower level for some.
"You don't have to show yourself losing a lot of weight," says Ames. "You can see it in your back."
The study was published Wednesday in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
Ames also said if the results are correct, marijuana treatment could help others, but it does not necessarily mean using pot to treat chronic pain. In other words, he says there are risks involved in using marijuana to treat severe pain and other health issues.
What if these findings signal to people that there are better ways to get better? The researchers call it potentializing.
The researchers call this such a "post-traumatic reflux," saying a person who was experiencing severe pain may develop the symptoms of "flammable mucus," affecting the gastrointestinal tract.
The researchers want to see what happens when medical marijuana inhibits one of the many symptoms associated with chronic pain. They plan to begin clinical studies in 2014 and is seeking $10 million in early 2011 for a clinical study. That study could then compare pot treatment to use in treating conditions like chronic knee pain.
Unlikely effects
Steve Kolchak, who is vice president for research, says THC treating patients with chronic pain makes sense. Depending on their status, they have to continue to use the drug. Even if the patient’s arthritis is no longer present, the therapy may be turned off.
A pain mitigation agent, as Ames calls it, is a for-profit drug maker which, says Ames, has spent billions of dollars to develop and commercialize medical marijuana. Selling these medications now to civilians may not be in their interest.
All of the cannabinoids created in pot can help those suffering from chronic pain suffer and, Kolchak notes, it's their favorite drug: Oxytocin. Oxytocin is a mixture of hormones and pharmaceuticals which have shown remarkable effects on pain control and other neurological conditions.
Loretta Magin, whose work on pain was published in the early 1970s in the journal Biological Psychiatry, says hers was not but if a prescription for opioids is approved, probably it won't help any. She will wait for an FDA hearing on the drug's effect.
Another pot expert sees a possible trick trick to marijuana treatment as well.
"It works the same way in all of the different classes," says David Elder, director of the Center for Cannabis Studies at Spelman College in Atlanta, where Stanford University and Princeton University came up with marijuana-infused therapy.
Elder says his research comes up with the potential of treating a variety of conditions including joint pain, but another drawback is that these patients are treated with a "way to show past medical marijuana use" regimen, like an antidepressant.
"And it all starts with a patient's handiwork. So there are no calories," says Elder. "You can have a placebo for a long period of time in order to understand the patient's way of getting help. The patient may be saying, 'This is going to help me and I want it.'"

title: The Health Benefits and Risks of Marijuana
text: The state of California's recent step toward fully decriminalizing the possession of small amounts of marijuana with Prop 19 has reignited one of the more contentious flash points in modern societywhere, if anywhere, marijuana has a place. Few things illustrate the controversy better than a comparison of the web pages that purport to separate myth from fact published by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Drug Policy Alliance (DPA). They are almost mirror images of one another, addressing the very same points, but drawing on different studies to reach their preferred conclusions. It's stunning to see how differently these agencies can interpret the same information. There is a single salvation from this cherry-picking point-counterpoint: the seminal report "Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base." This comprehensive summary of marijuana was written in 1999 by the most highly regarded nongovernmental medical organization in the country, the Institute of Medicine, and it serves as the primary source for the information in this article concerning the risks and benefits of marijuana. Health Risk Myths & Realities The essential questions are whether the active ingredient in marijuana, a cannabinoid (chemical compound) known as THC, has any medicinal value; whether the risks associated with its use outweigh the benefits; and whether THC answers a need not currently met by any other medications on the market. In the course of that debate, several health risks are often cited: Marijuana overdose There is no existing evidence of anyone dying of a marijuana overdose, but this doesn't preclude the possibility of experiencing adverse or unpleasant effects when it is consumed in large amounts. For comparison's sake, alcohol overdoses claim approximately 5,000 casualties per year.This is often cited as a reason that marijuana is safer than other drugs, like alcohol. Memory Marijuana does impair short-term memory, but only during intoxication. THC has been shown to have a negative effect on memory, and chronic abuse of marijuana will cause permanent impairment. Addiction The DEA's general opposition to marijuana is comprised of 1) that whatever medical value it has is already fulfilled by other, equally effective drugs on the market, and 2) that marijuana is highly addictive. Both points can be turned upside down: There is already an abundance of drugs that do the same job as products already on the market, and they receive approval anyway. This seems to run contrary to the DEA's first argument. And even a cursory look at many of the Schedule II opiates and amphetamines shows that high addiction potential is not a basis for legal classification of drugs. The point is that marijuana is not physically addictive, and even if it was, the DEA would appear to be quite hypocritical arguing this point. The immune system If smoked marijuana were to inhibit the activity of T-lymphocytes in the blood, it would compromise the body's ability to fight infection. This would put some people at the mercy of opportunistic infections and diseases, notably those who have immunosuppressive conditions like HIV or lymphoma . However, the data does not support this. What it does support -- barely -- is the compromised immunity of the lungs due to the smoke from marijuana. Heart problems It is accepted in medical circles today that marijuana use causes no evident long-term cardiovascular problems for normal persons. The DEA aggressively goes after this point, claiming that according to Harvard researchers, in the hour after having smoked marijuana, one's heart attack risk goes up five fold. However, this 'fact' is not properly cited and is indicative of the DEA's sloppy attempts to cite its sources. Marijuana's effects on blood pressure are complex and inconsistent as of yet. Cancer Is THC considered a carcinogen (cancer-causing) in humans? Not according to the two most esteemed agencies of relevance, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) and the U.S. National Toxicology Program (NTP). However, the same cannot be said for smoking marijuana, as the smoke from burning marijuana shares an array of dangerous and potentially carcinogenic chemicals with cigarette smoke. The DPA fumbles here, saying "there have been no reports of lung cancer related solely to marijuana," subtly hinting that it's even possible to determine causation for any cancer in the first place. It should be said that although the DPA's information is generally more reliable than the DEAs, it does contain its fair share of porous arguments. The gateway effect Does marijuana use lead to harder drugs? Most long-term studies show that those people who report having tried disparate drugs like cocaine and heroin often share a history of having smoked marijuana. However, the implication that marijuana causes people to try harder drugs is as yet unproven, and indeed it may act as an alternative to more dangerous drugs. Potential benefits No serious proponent of medicinal marijuana would claim it cures anything. Marijuana does, however, treat symptoms -- pain, nausea -- that are caused by a wide range of illnesses. Pain management The receptors in the brain that allow uptake of cannabinoids (like THC) are actually part of the most widespread receptor system in the body. Not only is the body naturally attuned to these molecules, it also uses them to great effect -- numerous studies have established that cannabinoids help reduce pain and other distressing symptoms. Antiemesis Some chemotherapy regimens are notorious for causing terrible bouts of nausea and vomiting, and both THC and marijuana have been explored as antiemetic (antinausea) medication. Smoking marijuana does give the desired effect in a matter of minutes and could, therefore, relieve the symptom quickly. The potential drawback If marijuana becomes fully legalized in plant form and open to commercialization -- a stance largely supported by the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws (NORML) -- one notoriously vile group of manufacturers is uniquely poised better than any other to take control of the emerging market: Big Tobacco. Having fully established its disinterest in the public health generations ago by the shady promotion of smoking, the idea of Big Tobacco becoming the nation's pot supplier should frighten anyone favoring legalization and regulation. Still much to learn The dearth of useful clinical trial datarandomized, controlled, double-blind trials involving large patient populationsis the biggest hurdle facing marijuana's legitimacy. While numerous smaller tests have been performed that support both sides of the health argument, political and economic reasons will form the primary impetus for the legalization of marijuana. For a state like California, whose budget deficit amounts to billions of dollars, the potential tax revenue from legalized marijuana is a lot of money that is currently going up in smoke.

By Ross Bonander

title: Study: Early Marijuana Use May Increase Brain Damage
text: Smoking marijuana at a young age causes more brain impairment than those who use the drug later in life or not at all, according to a study from McLean Hospital of the Harvard School of Medicine. The small study shows that smoking marijuana before the age of 16 leaves individuals with weakened executive function, such as planning, flexibility and abstract thinking. One of the tests conducted as part of the study included subjects being asked to sort a deck of cards following one set of rules, and then quickly switching to another set of rules without warning. The individuals who started smoking at an early age performed significantly worse than non-users and those who started using marijuana later in life. In other tests, early marijuana users continued to make the same errors repeatedly. The study included 33 young marijuana users and 26 non-users. Previous studies by neuroscientists had shown that those who smoke large amounts of marijuana on a regular basis do not do well on tests of memory and other mental abilities.
gens_article:
Babies born with defective hippocampal connections in their brains will likely have increased brain damage if they start smoking or taking marijuana, a major finding that underscores their stressful lives and stresses parents.
Researchers think marijuana, by contrast, will only have a modest effect on brain tissues and the production of essential hormones and neurotransmitters that would regulate body clocks.
Marijuana smoking is linked to long-term cognitive deficits and low IQs.
In a study published in the British Journal of Psychiatry, researchers say a small sample of babies born in Sweden where “marijuana use is considered moderate” showed the effect of marijuana on their hippocampal connections, a marker of chronic brain damage caused by adult smoking and other common harmful effects of marijuana.
“Our discovery represents another potentially effective treatment that has the potential to improve health and well-being by encouraging brain development through the use of cannabinoids, a substance derived from the marijuana plant, which currently is regulated as cannabis,” the study’s lead author Dr. Gayme Hetkin, a pediatric cardiologist at the Simon Fraser Medical School, said in a news release.
A significant number of Swedish babies with genetic disorders also used marijuana.
The London-based team is just one of dozens of scientists working on drugs that could one day help prevent, treat or reverse childhood mental and physical problems, said Paul McClure, a professor of psychology at Manchester United University and one of those lead researchers.
McClure, who was not involved in the British study, said more research will be needed to establish more precisely what the effects are of marijuana or whether marijuana helps people develop memory, thinking and others from an earlier age.
"This work should give us more insight into a range of reasons why cannabinoids are needed in order to safely and effectively treat not only those most at risk of reoccurring neurological conditions but those most at-risk of need for treatment," McClure said.
To learn more about the findings, watch Dr. Lisa Betta, a pediatric cardiologist at the University of Cambridge who is not involved in the British study, on foxnews.com.

title: Feds crack down on Colorado medical pot dispensaries
text: U.S. prosecutors in Colorado started a crackdown against nearly two dozen medical marijuana dispensaries located within 1,000 feet of schools, giving the proprietors 45 days to cease operations or face civil and criminal penalties. U.S. Attorney John Walsh issued the ultimatum in letters to 23 dispensaries and landlords he said were in violation of federal and state law, a statement Thursday from the U.S. Justice Department said. The move makes Colorado the latest battleground pitting federal prosecutors against storefront distributors of marijuana in states that have decriminalized marijuana for medical purposes. "When the voters of Colorado passed the limited medical marijuana amendment in 2000, they could not have anticipated that their vote would be used to justify large marijuana stores located within blocks of our schools," Walsh said. He cited a 2011 memo from U.S. Deputy Attorney General James Cole that allows individual federal prosecutors to "exercise their discretion to handle marijuana trafficking matters." The Colorado move followed an announcement in October by federal prosecutors in California that they were cracking down on medical pot dispensaries they said were fronts for large-scale, for-profit drug trafficking. Last March, federal agents also raided greenhouses and dispensaries in 13 cities in Montana cited by authorities as operating illegally under the guise of that state's medical marijuana law. A month later, U.S. attorneys in Washington state issued a legal opinion threatening to prosecute not only dispensary owners and growers but state officials who would have enforced a proposed state licensing system for medical marijuana. Washington Governor Christine Gregoire cited that warning in her decision to veto a bill to establish a new regulatory system for state-sanctioned suppliers of medicinal cannabis. A total of 16 states and the District of Columbia have enacted some sort of legalized medical-marijuana statutes, according to the National Drug Policy Alliance. But cannabis remains classified as an illegal narcotic under federal law, a point Walsh underscored in his letter to Colorado dispensary operators. "The dispensary is operating in violation of federal law, and the Department of Justice has the authority to enforce the federal law ... even when such activities may be permitted under state law," the letter said. Walsh did not identify any of the letter's recipients, except to say the businesses were located throughout the state. Denver lawyer Robert Corry, who represents clients charged with marijuana offenses, said in recent testimony before the Denver City Council that "there should be no arbitrary distance limits" for legal marijuana businesses. "There is no documented case of any child ever purchasing or obtaining medical marijuana from a dispensary," he said. Nevertheless, Walsh said law enforcement will be on the lookout for other violators, and offenders could be subject to asset seizure and property forfeitures. "Those who do not comply will be subject to potential criminal prosecution and civil enforcement actions," Walsh said. "Because the stores are operating within 1,000 feet of a school, enhanced penalties apply under federal law."

Colorado regulators have drawn national attention to one of the state's medical marijuana dispensaries that says it has agreed to stop selling its medicines for addiction.
The Marijuana Control Board will investigate the plan after lawmakers passed medical marijuana regulation in October, Fox News reported.
Plaintiffs previously had the company liable for legal expenses if it won a guilty verdict over illegally growing and selling its products, according to the Journal.
The state board previously passed the first of a series of rounds of inventory reviews the year before the ruling. In October, it found that more than half of the 1,000 medicine patients it took care of were receiving medical marijuana as a result of the initiative.
This week, state officials announced another round of inventory reviews and gave about 15 percent of dispensaries until Jan. 29 to comply.
The filing of an end-of-business letter comes as worries mount that local municipalities may resist attempts to legalize medical marijuana.
“We wish to express our concern to the Denver Post today that we have seen the effects of the state-mandated inventory reviews on our clients and to our own clients’ ability to remain a legitimate choice for treating patients,” Matthew Warthen, special agent in charge of the Denver office of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, said in a statement.
But Weld County District Attorney Steve Brown, who led the medicinal marijuana commission, also issued a statement after the board met Wednesday.
"We all understand there is little point in a trial considering, 'The path forward for regulating cannabis businesses is based on rules that apply uniformly in a Colorado public health system,'" Brown said.
Like first-year research estimates, the state now says the medical marijuana industry in Colorado has not expanded beyond about 5,000 people, except for 1,000 patients in Greeley, Lyons, Cherry Hills and Grayslake, which is located west of Denver.
In a few years, the nation will be prompted to consider the impact of medical marijuana, but in terms of output and impact on price, "we can’t control that," state spokesman Kevin Hardin said.
But in a letter to the U.S. Attorney’s Office, Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper said that the state’s direction is influenced by reports that show over a million patients are being served with pot.
“Medical marijuana remains an important option for Colorado patients in the area of addiction,” he said. “We are taking the necessary steps to assist individuals facing chronic pain, hunger and increased job risk.”
The decision to send the officials back to Denver could lead to more scrutiny from the health boards, though not necessarily time-consuming, marijuana activists.
"My suspicion is that the [marijuana commission has] reached an impasse," Warthen said.
"What this puts on them is how far along the commission is in writing their program and how far ahead they are at running it. It's up to them to decide what they want to do."

title: Concern growing over synthetic marijuana
text: Three U.S. teenagers ended up in the emergency department with altered mental states and seriously elevated heart rates after smoking synthetic marijuana, doctors say in a new report that adds to earlier evidence the popular drug can be dangerous. One 16-year-old girl who was brought in by her boyfriend refused to move or speak and did not respond when doctors rubbed her chest hard or pinched her. Although she was lying down, her pulse was 105. She only came back around after getting two kinds of medications -- an anti-anxiety drug and one that's used to treat abnormal movements -- and resting for several hours. While her urine test was positive for THC, one of the active ingredients in natural marijuana, her boyfriend said they had also smoked K2, one of the many names for synthetic marijuana. The drugs were recently banned in the U.S. and the Drug Enforcement Administration has proposed to classify them permanently as schedule 1 controlled substances -- a category that includes heroin and natural marijuana. The synthetic versions are blends of herbs and spices laced with cannabis-like chemicals, and are sold under a variety of names, including Spice, K2 and Red X Dawn. The synthetic drugs are believed to be much stronger than regular pot, however, and the products may include other ingredients, too. "Because it's unregulated we don't know exactly what's in it," said Dr. Joanna Cohen, one of the authors of the new report, which was published Monday in the journal Pediatrics. The two other cases involved both involved teenage boys. One of them, an 18-year-old, was brought to the ER from a party, where he had gotten into an altercation. He was aggressive, agitated and sweating profusely and had a pulse of 131. The other, a 16-year-old, seemed confused and agitated and had trouble speaking. Both teens calmed down after getting an anti-anxiety drug and were discharged from the hospital after a number of hours. Both teens had a negative drug screen, but said they had been smoking synthetic pot, which isn't detectable on standard drug tests. Cohen, an emergency physician at Children's National Medical Center in Washington, D.C., said the three cases described in her report are the only ones she has witnessed personally. But last November, a team of Texas doctors published a report on three 16-year-olds who had experienced heart attacks after smoking synthetic cannabis. And according to Cohen and her colleagues, poison control centers across the country have received 4,500 calls involving the products since 2010. "If people were getting the effects that they wanted they probably wouldn't be calling the poison control centers," she told Reuters Health. "Anytime your teenager is acting abnormally or having aggressive agitation you should certainly seek medical attention."

Growing popularity on the street due to the role of synthetic marijuana in California's marijuana industry has prompted questions on who will regulate the product, a public health agency said Friday.
With the worst drought in seven decades -- and increases in wildlife and crime -- the question mark stands at the public health and environmental health implications of synthetic marijuana, which many believe should still be sold on the black market.
San Jose-based PETA took the lead on a petition campaign to persuade state lawmakers to ban the sale of synthetic marijuana on their state parks, aquariums and beaches.
"It's unbelievable, in and of itself," said Christopher Jannangelo, director of the Animal Services Division of the California Department of Animal Care and Control. "They're taking it on the road to a connection with Los Angeles," citing the city's water shortage.
Increased consumer awareness in synthetic marijuana traffic, for example, "offers the potential of a state that has now fallen into the hands of a lot of people who do bad things for nobody else," Jannangelo said.
Robert Sittenbroek, a professor at Ohio University's Division of Veterinary Medicine, is expected to testify before the legislature on the problem, said Janice Gage, president of the Rancho Flores Veterinary Medical Center in Mesquite, Texas.
Gage, the leading proponent of the bill, said such a prohibition would add to traffic and lead to tighter rules in California. The bill would also allow for the sale of the "real thing," or even banned uses of synthetic marijuana, she said.
Although the overwhelming majority of Californians support the consumption of synthetic marijuana, that number includes about half of residents who serve cooking classes on the illegal drugs.
The PETA petition campaign, created on April 30, calls on lawmakers to deny permission to sell synthetic marijuana to people without proper medical information. Instead, they would be allowed to "couple" the product with research to understand how it affects people, many of whom use illegal drugs, Gage said.
PETA and other opponents of California's ban cite a lack of proper background checks and to elaborate on harmful side effects, including hospitalizations from synthetic marijuana.
Several dispensaries have formed in recent years and have drawn substantial numbers of customers. For several weeks in December, the lead sponsor of the effort -- the City of Carson -- initially worried that sales would run into legitimate parking lots as a deterrent to prospective customers and let more cafes up and down the street.
The owners faced legal troubles for the sale of synthetic marijuana. The city charged two high school graduates with misdemeanor possession, and a 45-year-old man was sentenced to two days in jail. Four days after the arrests, the Los Angeles Times reported that an undercover investigator found six packets of the drug in a donation jar at an illegal online seller.
A single packet of the heroin contained one kilogram of the drug, which meant more than 100 people would have to be arrested and taxed for the drug.
The San Francisco Examiner reported that:
For example, a lone male got scared inside a restaurant's kitchen, three girls slipped inside, and six adults got caught in a hallway.
Citywide revenue is expected to be between $6 million and $8 million, according to city projections.
"Since synthetic cannabis is controlled by the attorney general, the impact of this in California could be minimal," said Timothy Burns, head of the PETA oncology section.

title: Researchers study neuroprotective properties in cannabis
text: With more states opting to legalize the sale of medical marijuana , researchers are taking a closer look at the use of cannabis to treat chronic illnesses. Dr. Manny Alvarez, senior managing health editor of XXX, recently sat down with the Medicine Hunter, Chris Kilham, to find out how its being studied. Dr. Manny: Now from the medical marijuana perspective, as far as the treatment of chronic illnesses, what is it about cannabis that makes it that special? Medicine Hunter: Well, it seems that there are primarily two things there's the THC, that's what people associated with getting high. And that appears to have a saliatory effect on the eyes in case of glaucoma . For people who are suffering from chemotherapy and can't eat, it helps to get their appetite back. And we also know that it is a potent pain reliever and science on that goes back to the 1890s. But theres another agent in cannabis that is getting more attention now, and that is called cannabidiol. And this is something that you can swallow by the bucket-full, and it won't get you high at all. But it appears to have profound nerve-protective and brain-enhancing properties. And interestingly enough, it also induces an anti-anxiety effect. So this appears to be a very important agent, perhaps useful in the treatment of neurodegenerative disorders. DM: Are they extracting that particular chemical off the marijuana? MH: There seem to be two pathways that people are taking. You've got G.W. pharmaceuticals in Britain that has come out with a whole cannabis fluid spray. You've got people also isolating cannabidiol and playing with that in the lab. I don't know how this is all going to settle out I mean, as a whole-plant person, I'm inclined toward the whole extract. But it does appear that this may also have anti-cancer properties, and that's very intriguing. DM: Is marijuana addictive? MH: I would say that people can absolutely become dependent upon it. But not physiologically addictive. And, as you know, that's not just parsing terms I mean physiological addiction, you go through very grave withdrawal. But people can become dependent on it just as they can on any substance. DM: Tell me about this study in the American Journal of Pediatrics talking about pregnant Jamaican women and the use of pot. MH: Melanie Dreher, who is the dean of nursing at Rush Medical Center in Chicago , did a study in Jamaica . It was actually published in the American Journal of Pediatrics in 1994, but now it's re-circulating because of all the interest in the neuroprotective properties. Basically, she studied women during their entire pregnancy, and then studied the babies about a year after birth. And what she studied was a group of women who did smoke cannabis during pregnancy and those who didn't. She expected to see a difference in the babies as far as birth weight and neuro tests, but there was no difference whatsoever. The differences that the researchers did notice, that are unexplained and kind of curious are that the babies of the women who had smoked cannabis -- and we're talking about daily use during their pregnancy -- socialized more quickly, made eye contact more quickly and were easier to engage. We don't know why this is so, but all the old saws of smoking during pregnancy will result in low birth weight did not show up -- at least in the Jamaican study. In U.S. studies where we've seen a similar investigation, women have concurrently been abusing alcohol and other drugs as well. Alvarez said its interesting to note that there may be neuroprotective properties present in cannabis and the cannibidiol extract, but that smoking of any kind in pregnant women is discouraged. More research is needed when it comes to medical marijuana, he added.

When the blood stream monitors the effects of THC metabolites found in cannabis, it may help doctors to predict their patients’ benefits, researchers say.
The research — which was published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS) — suggests those findings may help answer some of the questions that doctors wrestle with as they try to help explain some of the most popular and dangerous forms of marijuana use in the United States.
Those types of deaths are known to be associated with fewer treatment options or a shorter follow-up period for patients suffering from epilepsy.
"Perhaps a potent stimulant that may be helpful during these cycles of ingestion could be considered even more potent at night, which tends to lead to painful drug overdoses," researcher Kurt Jerder told FoxNews.com.
His team also found that those who consumed cannabis in the past six weeks, while their bodies were still producing the drug, showed lower pain-relief reports after two-thirds of those who consumed cannabis had clinically equivalent or better pain relief.
They suggest this can be because of the combination of marijuana’s psychoactive properties and its potential to temporarily improve pain management.
Worried patients who regularly inhale the drug are more likely to underreport the findings so that they may mistakenly claim they have avoided THC from the blood stream, Jerder said.
"This can be a bit of a wake-up call for physicians when they come across something like this," he said.
Researchers didn’t create the drug using illicit substances that are readily available at retail stores and pharmacists. Instead, the team focused on a chronic condition such as schizophrenia, which involves a strong relationship with a major psychoactive substance.
The team found over four years that although patients spent approximately 37 percent of their time chewing the drug, it was not at the expense of their mental health.
Stimulating early movement also increased concentration at night compared to those who smoked, particularly going a night when the drug was synthesized first, the team reports.
But researchers thought the results should apply to PTSD, rather than chemotherapy, because most patients with the disorder have similar symptoms.
This new study also found that while marijuana over-indulges menopause, the study focused more on alcohol consumption.
The research team wanted to assess whether current treatments and pre-existing psychological conditions promote the recreational use of cannabis.
"People who have a primary symptom of smoking cannabis won’t necessarily be happy with the treatment," Jerder said.
Earlier studies also have shown such effects and that cannabis and alcohol play a central role in the brain and other nervous systems.
Whether or not to limit use in physicians’ offices, Jerder said the evidence is there and could be useful, if those studies show these clinical effects.
"We believe that the trials and knowledge gained from these studies will help us to assess if these cannabinoid effects occur in patients who are trained to take a nonsurgical measure as more of a risk factor for having high, and to make use of marijuana at home," Jerder said.
The research does not directly address such benefits, but it provides other useful information on cannabis for patients, Jerder said.
"Our findings suggest that medicines may be useful for other cancers and other chronic diseases. We may also be able to measure effects of cannabis, such as reduced intake of the opioid that causes pain and depression, thus working better for patients with the primary symptoms of depression," he said.

title: CDC: More US teens smoke marijuana than cigarettes
text: A government survey shows more teens are now smoking pot than cigarettes. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported Thursday that 23 percent of high school students said they recently smoked marijuana, while 18 percent said they had puffed cigarettes. The survey asked teens about a variety of risky behaviors. For decades, the number of teens who smoke has been on the decline. Marijuana use has fluctuated, and recently rose. At times, pot and cigarette smoking were about the same level, but last year marked the first time marijuana use was clearly greater. An earlier survey by the University of Michigan also found that pot smoking was higher. A Michigan expert said teens today apparently see marijuana as less dangerous than cigarettes.
gens_article:
It may sound like some folks just took pot for another reason – to numb the pain of chronic addictions.
But the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that nearly 1 in 4 U.S. adolescents currently smoke marijuana and 2 in 4 are prescribed marijuana with another prescribed drug.
And nine out of 10 of these people, at the age of 25 and over, said they’ve smoked weed and are hooked on it, the CDC said Wednesday.
Overall, 19.4 million kids have been asked to study their risk of alcohol and tobacco use in America. The CDC said that numbers have grown all year and are about 80 percent higher than the rate of overall teen smoking and alcohol use.
Here are some key findings from the report:
• Nearly 5 million people ages 20 to 29 said they smoke pot, a figure that nearly doubles the percentages of the population. In 2014, that number is expected to more than double. In a 2011 poll by Dr. Thomas Frieden, chairman of the CDC, he indicated the rate of daily marijuana use is not expected to rise.
• For the first time, 5.1 million kids said they or someone they know has been prescribed marijuana, compared with 1.9 million in 2010.
“This increase in use and awareness is a major turnoff to heroin users,” Frieden said.
There’s a problem.
The CDC said there were 244,000 youth ages 15 to 19 in 2010 where they received a drug report – about 4 percent of all teen users. In 2010, 3 percent of the kids were prescribed medical marijuana, the drug the CDC calls “drugs like Xanax and Vicodin.”
The number of opioid prescriptions has also exploded in the U.S.
Nearly 9 million prescriptions had been written to obtain the anti-narcotics drug, which also is commonly prescribed by doctors. About six percent of those prescriptions were filled by people under the age of 18.
“When we’re talking about growth rates that are unprecedented for all pediatricians, and are startling in the general population,” said Dr. Atiqul Islam, the chief of behavioral health for Boston Children’s Hospital.
It’s unclear how many kids have prescribed marijuana. The CDC said its guess is more than 200,000.
But, at least for the younger group of kids, there’s just one reliable way to check that.
Aerobic exercise may help, according to Dr. Jerome Arthur, a pediatricians and lead author of the report. As long as people have no other difficult reasons to take pot, he said, they’re taking it as a preventive measure that doesn’t add to their pain levels. And don’t get too excited if they’re trying to plan future trips.

title: One in eight with fibromyalgia uses cannabis as medicine
text: One in eight people with the painful condition fibromyalgia self-medicate with pot and other cannabis products, according to a new Canadian study. "That is not unusual behavior, in general, for people with chronic medical illnesses for which we don't have great treatments," said Dr. Igor Grant, who heads the Center for Medicinal Cannabis Research at the University of California and was not involved in the study. "People start looking around, they look for other types of remedies, because they need the help," he told Reuters Health. The question is if self-medicating with cannabis is really helpful for people with fibromyalgia, researchers say. Marijuana has been shown to ease certain types of pain in patients with HIV and other conditions. But Grant said he doesn't know of any research showing the drug can relieve the pain associated with fibromyalgia. And the question of whether it helps fibromyalgia sufferers regain some of their daily functions, such as housekeeping or working, remains up in the air, too. "We don't want to just see pain reduction, but an improvement in function," said Peter Ste-Marie, a pain researcher at McGill University in Montreal, who worked on the new study. "If it's not helping them get back into a daily life pattern, is it helping them?" People with fibromyalgia typically experience pain in their joints and muscles and may also suffer from frequent headaches and fatigue. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, about two percent of adults have fibromyalgia, which remains a mystery to scientists. The condition can be treated with physical therapy, antidepressants, pain medications and other approaches, although none of them is a cure. To see how many people turn to marijuana, Ste-Marie and his colleagues collected information from the medical records of 457 patients who came to the pain unit at McGill University Health Center. Their findings are published in the journal Arthritis Care & Research. All of the patients had been referred to the clinic for fibromyalgia symptoms, although only 302 of the patients were confirmed to have fibromyalgia as their primary diagnosis. About 10 percent said they smoked marijuana for medical purposes and another three percent had a prescription for a synthetic form of the active chemical in the cannabis plant. "The popular knowledge of marijuana being available for pain would tend to demonstrate why 10 percent of patients would give it a try," said Ste-Marie. "There really is no miracle drug for fibromyalgia. We definitely understand that patients would try to find something else," he told Reuters Health. The researchers couldn't tell from the study which of the patient had started smoked pot before their fibromyalgia developed. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, about 40 percent of U.S. adults have tried marijuana at some point. The study showed that pot smokers and non-users had the same rates of disability and unemployment. However, patients who had unstable mental illness or had a worrisome use of opioid pain medications were more likely to report using cannabis - a finding that raised concerns with Ste-Marie and his colleagues. "Before saying herbal cannabis has a future in fibromyalgia, there are multiple things that need to be looked at," he said.
gens_article:
According to the 2012 World Health Organization (WHO), 40 percent of people with fibromyalgia use cannabis to relieve their pain.
Moxi Pharmaceuticals and Chinese company Ubel Pharmaceuticals formed a joint venture (JFC-to-Ubel) in 2011 to expand an existing synthetic cannabinoid family of compounds called MMX to include alternative medicine therapies.
The deal, to be announced today, will have Ubel selling another MMX compound called Acaduo for use in fibromyalgia. MMX is a plant extract derived from fiber often found in marijuana strains.
Fibromyalgia – characterized by facial and body aches, chronic, and debilitating pain—religiously affects the northern hemisphere and ranges from man-made to structural. It is triggered by a protein that promotes the relaxation effect of their systemic joints and muscles.
MMX is considered a drug for a host of medical conditions—from psoriasis to cancer. According to the White Helmets, some estimates suggest that the drug is a 5 percent to 10 percent cheaper than conventional drugs.
But experts note that this alternative drug is not indicated for those of poor health or exercise quality due to its incomplete construction and lack of cellular function.
"Based on the data out there, we do not expect that the side effects are in the guidelines."
According to data from the National Institutes of Health, more than 2,000 patients and 1,200 caregivers have been diagnosed with fibromyalgia. Those hospitalized in 2015, 2,388, "have not been able to manage their pain due to fibromyalgia," said Doug Shapiro, a physician researcher with NIRM. In addition, more than 86 percent have had less than moderate pain levels.
But several modifications have been made to the drug including a lower dose of MMX, a decrease in doses, and extra dosage.
Vivian Tamihud, a nurse practitioner in New York City, developed a patient psychiatrist’s report that showed that people who use MMX are more likely to have their fibromyalgia “go on” during the peak years of their recovery.
Tihud, whose son is also diagnosed with fibromyalgia, also claims to have “an overwhelming medical experience” with fibromyalgia.
“The problems many people with fibromyalgia have have been grappling with at an early stage: debilitating back pain, fibromyalgia-like coagulation, and high gastrointestinal enzymes with many of the symptoms of my own long term fibromyalgia,” says Tamihud.

title: Porsche aims high with hemp-bodied car
text: Porsches smoking hot new race car is the worlds first with bodywork built from hemp. The 718 Cayman GT4 Clubsport features composite doors that use an organic fiber mix derived largely from hemp and flax that take the place of traditional carbon fiber to reinforce a polymer resin. Porsche says the material is similar in weight and stiffness to a traditional carbon fiber composites and that the organic ingredients used are agricultural by-products, making it more environmentally friendly. (Ford) Porsche isnt the first automaker with this sort of idea, however. Back in 1941 Henry Ford built a prototype with a body made entirely from plastic that reportedly used cellulose from hemp, wheat and soybeans in its construction, although the exact formula has been lost to history. Along with the weight-reduction provided by the doors, the stripped-out Clubsport features a 425 hp 3.8-liter flat-six engine, 6-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, racing seats, roll cage, fuel cell, racing brakes and suspension, plus additional equipment for track use. Two versions are being offered: a $150,000 Trackday model and a Competition version aimed at top-level racing that costs $175,000. (Porsche) Porsche hasnt indicated any plans to use the new material on a street legal production car, but its improved sustainability would further enhance the green image of its upcoming lineup of electric vehicles.
gens_article:
After experiencing a glut of inventory at its retail outlets, the Porsche family is once again battling to fill up. Starting next week, Volkswagen plans to begin selling the Bugatti Veyron Sport Alpine Sport, to be powered by a hemp-inspired vehicle.
Automated connections will provide access to market volume with a lot of new premium ones already on the market. This allows Volkswagen to experiment with engines that combine the aerospace-inspired stability characteristics of the Veyron Sport, and to create exotic off-road vehicles that meet Air testing standards. The paint and the all-new turbo engine will also be incorporated into the new G20 diesel Sport, which will be capable of churning out 70 horsepower in under seven seconds.
With the latest additions to the Bugatti Veyron Sport, European names and major brands are also targeting the Russian market for future test deliveries. Besides the car manufacturing facility at Muirfield, Opel is expected to begin driving the supercar for International Volkswagen Sports Expo in Los Angeles by the end of this year.
Tuktu Pitti Diamu, CEO of Bugatti Group, reports that we are on the verge of another supercar, this time in the form of the 2019 Frontier.
As for the car’s more modern diesel engine and the best model in the Veyron Sport, the SEMA car with a turbocharger is generating some commendable market demand.
With six-speed manual gearbox and a 2.0-liter V8 turbocharged engine, the Veyron Sport also features turbocharging technology that allows the driver to control the engine through a mobile control system. The wheelbase is significantly smaller than the Veyron Sport’s much larger footprint, and the shifting arrangement to support a turbo only makes the car more agile and safer for drivers.
If you’re a collector of Volkswagens, these images and videos would be the perfect complement to your personal automobile collection.

title: Brad Pitt says he turned to marijuana, hiding from public amid immense fame in 1990s
text: Brad Pitt admitted that the pressures of his immense fame in the 1990s caused him to turn to marijuana and seclusion in order to cope. In an in-depth interview with The New York Times Magazine, Pitt, who rose to fame with hit films such as Interview with the Vampire , Seven and Fight Club throughout the decade, said that he spent a good portion of the '90s sequestered in private because he didnt know how to react to the public interest in his every move and decision. I spent most of the 90s hiding out and smoking pot, he told the outlet . I was too uncomfortable with all the attention. Pitt, 55, said by the early 2000s he realized that he was imprisoning himself with his lifestyle of avoidance. Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie divorced in 2016. (Evan Agostini/Invision/AP, File) Now I go out and live life, and generally people are pretty cool, he explained. Pitt spent the next few years starring in more hit films and getting married to his Mr. and Mrs. Smith co-star, Angelina Jolie . However, after the couple split in 2016 , hes been thrust back into the public eye for more than his movie roles. In the interview, the star opened up about his relationship with fame today and how he manages to live his life without going back into hiding. In short, he simply stopped reading the stories that are being written about him. Not just reviews. I mean any magazine in the doctor's office," he said. "Because some of it would bounce around like a rat in the skull. It would stay there, and it would inform some of my decisions and choices in work, in life, and I didnt find any of it helpful."
gens_article:

He was not unfazed by the pressures of the public appearances, but he confessed to hiding behind the veil of public morality in some ways.

There has been talk about fatherhood, Pitt revealed, but while attending the Capote Private Library in London last month, the actor spoke extensively about his plans for a series of children's books.

title: Scientists discover hormone that blocks pot "high"
text: French researchers have discovered that a naturally occurring hormone acts as a defense in the brain against the psychoactive effects of marijuana consumption. The hormone, pregnenolone reduces the activity of a brain molecule that acts as a cannabinoid receptor. Researches think the discovery could help people with addictions to marijuana, as well as allowing people to take medical marijuana without the behavioral effects. The study was published in the journal Science . About 147 million people globally or about 2.5 percent of the population use cannabis, according to the World Health Organization.
gens_article:
Travitticinal growth hormone (TGH) was found to reduce the risk of high-risk growth, it turns out. In fact, it may help us develop significantly better green lungs from beer and cocktails.
The work has huge implications for people who already struggle with high-risk stem cell cancer, "things that we've always wanted to do because they have its effect on human tissue," explains Dr. David Cohen, professor of optometry at Harvard Medical School.
Instead of looking at patients with high-risk mutations, which can be a big deal, researchers at Massachusetts General Hospital are looking at patients at 400 potential sites in the U.S. in order to understand how TGH works, and in other developed countries, scientists are already doing their first step on their goal.
TGH “is a complex, highly induced and very direct intervention that we can't, or shouldn't, take," Cohen says.
Although the biological signature suggests it "has the potential to deliver cancer treatment drugs like benzodiazepines and anti-anxiety medications,” it still shouldn't tell patients who already carry high risk that they're low on them.
“Even without the effects of TGH, probably not all of these drugs have improved your cancer risk,” Cohen adds.
Heartland NanoChip that may slow fetal growth and keep tumors from morphing into larger tumors, is related to TGH. Less than a quarter of human stem cells can make its way into the bloodstream, meaning TGH makes babies more responsive to insulin, more likely to live and presumably longer.
All of this leads to the optimal design. And all of that leads to the benign part of the brain, the power of which is seen in the ability to write and interpret code.
This tissue is growing up to serve as a repository of potential health, and by studying it using early-stage neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's, Cohen says he hopes to help people find a therapeutic target to reduce our risk of high-risk cancer.

title: Justin Bieber released after plane stopped on suspicion of carrying pot
text: The troubled and talented Justin Bieber From a YouTube sensation to an award winning star. Will Justin Bieber be able to get his career and life back on track following a series of arrests and run-ins with the law? Justin Bieber and his entourage were held at Teterboro airport in New Jersey Friday after officials suspected the pop singer's plane was carrying marijuana, but sniffer-dogs came up empty and all aboard were released, The New York Post's Page Six reported. The pop star who had chartered a jet for his dad and entourage of friends was on his way to Super Bowl pre-parties, according to TMZ . The plane had just arrived when U.S. Customs officials detected a strong odor of pot, Page Six reported. The plane was ordered held until drug-sniffing dogs could check it out. Officers were sent to Bieber’s room at the hotel after a bottle of marijuana was found in his purse on the ground floor of the hotel hotel suite, police said.
Rikers Island, with its thousands of inmates who get out during the week, is one of the most expensive prisons in the country. In addition to drugs, the Orleans, Louisiana prison has a slew of crime scenes and much of the time is drug-involved.
A source close to Bieber told CNN Wednesday that he is “under the care of the medical team” and was taking legal steps to try to avoid charges.

title: Pot-growing neighbors blamed for fire that killed import cars, dogs
text: A few days ago, we brought you news on marijuana's danger to drivers . Today, we bring you news on marijuana's danger to cars. Earlier this month, a fire at International Vehicle Importers , a Southern California company that specializes in bringingJapanese carsto the United States, destroyed much of the inventory. The cause of the blaze wasn't initially known, but now the owner of the company is blaming a pot-growing operation in an adjacent warehouse. "After the fire, it was discovered that an illegal (in Ontario, California) marijuana grow was moving in next door," Sean Morris, the owner of International Vehicle Importers, wrote on Facebook . "There was activity all day on Sunday next door, just prior to the fire. The thoughts are that they overloaded the main power breakers and this caused the fire." Twenty-four cars were lost in the fire, which occurred May 1, including several 1990 Nissan SkylineGT-Rand GTS models, a 1989NissanCefiro, 1989ToyotaSoarer, and a '94 Eunos/MazdaCosmo, along with several motorhomes andmotorcycles. Most important, Morris and his family lost two dogs, Max and Gigi, in the fire. Police officials have yet to confirm the link between the fire and a marijuana-growing operation next door, though Morris posted pictures of a search warrant and apparent plant on his Facebook page. He writes the business wasinsured, and that it still has cars en route from Japan and more at its Long Beach location. "Along with business items, the dogs, and some spare parts, we also had some personal items that were being stored at the warehouse," he said. "Thank you for all the support out there. You know who you are."

Fox40 has contacted the U.S. Customs Service and the agency’s public records department about the complaints from Monroe Township residents that their residents were in danger of being taken out of business. Officials at Liberty-Clay County were unaware of the media reports and declined to comment.
Others questioned the town’s history with prosecuting suspects in the Redmans fire case, including Dena Bangor and Logan Tharrell. Bangor was one of four people arrested in early March for allegedly running their own auto salvage businesses. Taylor Walthall, who has two children of his own in the same neighborhood, speculated that the cars started to get embers from the blaze when it suddenly picked up speed. He said he had never seen a fire nearly as destructive as the one that destroyed his home.
“We’ve seen a couple years ago on the other side,” Walthall said. “To me, it’s just evil and I don’t want anybody else to suffer it, but I just don’t think this was a natural disaster.”
A spokesperson for the Commerce Department told FOX40 Tuesday that the auto salvage business is approved under the federal Department of Commerce for “trespassing” because of the properties’ proximity to roads.
The Monroe Township Fire Department said “restrictions on resale salvage operations involve significant defects or failures to properly inspect an automobile,” Walthall’s wife, Lamia, said in a statement.
Jack Ho, owner of a Timmins antiques store, said he found out Tuesday afternoon from Fox40 what was going on Wednesday when he received a email on his client’s list from police officials.

title: Tommy Chong says 'stay high' amid potential pot crackdown
text: Tommy Chong has a message for those fearing a crackdown on recreational marijuana use: Don't worry. Stay High. Chong shot to fame in the 1970s alongside Cheech Marin as the stoner comedy duo Cheech & Chong. After White House press secretary Sean Spicer told reporters Thursday that the Department of Justice "will be further looking into" recreational pot use, Chong tweeted, "Of course Trump is going after legal marijuana but like the failed Muslim ban it will be defeated in court. Don't worry stay High." Chong has a line of marijuana products on the market in states where pot is legal.
gens_article:
Tommy Chong, the Chinese comedian who's embroiled in a serious case of pot pot, says he "still stay high" because he feels more of a part of the country's youth.
Chong, who makes his television debut Wednesday on a new comedy show, said he's still feeling the effects of a political awakening at the young age of 35, particularly the notion that legalized marijuana was used improperly by whites, blacks and some youth. He also said that he's become more active in politics in the past few years since he started using pot in his show "Cheers," where he taps into the deep-rooted discontent of middle-class Chinese youth.
Chong was interviewed Wednesday on live television, a few hours after it aired on Channel 5 of Chong's hit television show "Cheers." He apologized Monday for cursing at a crowd of police after a homophobic bar fight in Hong Kong.
Chong's lengthy remarks about how the province is pushing young, unemployed people to become pot growers came to a conclusion following a police raid on his Sydney home. According to Chong, officers found hundreds of pot plants, 26 pipes and a small can of cheapening spray.
"Whatever the drug consumption was, they found the whole world's information, and the whole world had to know it," Chong said. "And it was perfectly reasonable to be careful," he added.
Chong's interview with Channel 5 ended on a note of surprise. Chong said he was surprised that City Hall, which had backed a proposal for voters to decide whether the province would legalize recreational marijuana in Hong Kong, would ask citizens to vote if they think pot is a danger.
He compared those responding to his statement that the legalization of pot was dangerous to young people with the warnings made in a statement posted on Chong's social media page. Chong said most young people would be better off if they thought marijuana was dangerous.
"I see the difference between pot I thought was a terrible danger and pot I thought it was a great danger. Then, when I read that comment on Twitter, I thought I would never miss it anymore. I don't want to miss any, either," Chong said.
Chong said a group of liberal activists conspired with law enforcement to stop him last year from further posting his controversial views on social media. But he said the police acted appropriately and allowed him to use his Twitter account.
Aminaz Ching, the lawyer who had prosecuted Chong for criticizing police in a video that have also provoked widespread outrage online, said Chong apologized Monday to the Hong Kong police and that he was determined to get his charges dropped.
Chong has not been charged for the broadcast of his comments. His lawyer, who has not been named, said Chong had been ordered to repay the fees and cost of a recording that could have had a net gain of a few million dollars for his lawyer.
Chong has apologized for the remarks last year on Twitter and repeated his apologies after becoming embroiled in a row with the police. His lawyer said this latest exchange was not all that inflammatory.
"I didn't say that he was kidding. The statement was irreverent, kind of insensitive, too," Khaled, his lawyer, said. "But it said that no one would ever know if it was a joke, it was just a joke."

title: Melissa Etheridge smokes pot with her kids: 'It brings you much closer'
text: Melissa Etheridge likes to smoke marijuana with her family, she revealed as part of Yahoos Weed & the American Family project, previewed by People . It was funny at first, and then they realized, its a very natural, end-of-the-day [thing] And it brings you much closer. Id much rather have a smoke with my grown kids than a drink oh, God, no. When I hold it without shame or confusion, then they can understand it as simple as if I was pointing to a bottle of Percocet and said, Thats Mamas medicine. gens_article:
Music icon Melissa Etheridge has spoken out about her daughter's marijuana habit in many, many places.
"I have some very, very, very close friends in my life," Etheridge told Billboard. "I have very close people in my music, and they're good friends. And I've done my best to get them to realize the terrible consequences of their behavior. So maybe my daughter and I are in and out of the marijuana lifestyle today."
When Brandy Eleto decided to buy a carton of marijuana, Etheridge knew it would be difficult to handle without the cannabis.
"At first I was angry," Etheridge told Billboard. "That's what I called it, how do I take off my anger and back my anger and I took off my rage and kind of grow up a little bit. But then I realized that there are things that are funny, that are very, very funny. My life wasn't rock 'n' roll, it wasn't that great. So I wrote in the book, 'A Mother's Work' [about] how the marijuana trail ended to death. Maybe she was cheating on me, or things like that."
Etheridge adopted a marijuana lifestyle that had led her down the same path. But while Etheridge didn't quite bring herself to go to the police about the pot use, she did have a helping hand for her daughter.
"In 1993 I had just six months left on my marriage and I had on six weeks left before to have another child. I came out of that really light. I was still working and it just kept getting deeper and deeper, what was taking longer and even longer. So my marriage really took off. I was speaking out, and you know, I said, 'It is the law. It's not okay.' My family lived with me, but I went through something like, 'Oh, it's okay. I can do this.' A couple of years ago I came out, for that reason, I brought my daughter across to Sacramento (Calif.) for the first time. It was just this crazy experience and it stuck with me forever. So it was my intention to tell her so she could speak to somebody. I said, 'Before I leave, I hope she can go see my family.' And I didn't have a license.
"I never once thought of pot as a bad thing," Etheridge said. "And I was never thinking of pot being evil. It wasn't 'How can you remove it from your life?' It was, 'How can you disallow it?' [I didn't want to] rid myself of it because I've always tried to. I didn't want to re-jigger my life. I just wanted to try to be one thing. But I was 21 and all of a sudden, I had this one thing that was weed-intolerant, but I didn't really want it. But I did. So, it is the law. If it's okay, let it happen."
Etheridge also visited with her daughter, Veronica, in case anyone couldn't tell.
"When my kids grew up, my husband and I are good friends. She told me, 'Please don't even get in a car with me,'" Etheridge explained. "So we bought her pot. She bought her marijuana. But it was great for her. She really was a good girl, like me. I was just really happy for her. Because you don't wanna know when someone is stealing that they take it."
The singer also addressed her very public struggle with bipolar disorder.
"I experienced a lot of times that I'm afraid that I'm bipolar. I'm anxious, I can't believe that I'm scared to be vulnerable. I've been struck by that as a professional artist, a longtime artist. When I first had these ideas and when I saw some of my friends' songs on streaming sites and artists are up and running on top, like Madonna, we called a mind numbing drug and I finally realized that that's what I needed to do, I needed to take something serious with me. And I came back in the middle of doing everything right," Etheridge said.

title: Busy Philipps: Seth Rogen gave me pot on 'Freaks and Geeks'
text: Call this the worst secret kept in Hollywood. "Cougar Town" star Busy Philipps appeared on Bravo's "Watch What Happens Live " on Wednesday, and was honest when a viewer asked who the biggest stoner was on the set of NBC's "Freaks and Geeks." Though host Andy Cohen initially guessed James Franco, Philipps said that Franco doesn't do pot, and revealed that it was actually Rogen who used to provide her with weed. "Yeah, I would say Seth," she shrugs. "He used to give me my pot, so ..." According to the 35-year-old actress, it was high quality product. Rogen has been open about his marijuana infatuation before, even offering to be rapper Waka Flocka Flame's personal blunt roller in September. Waka Flocka Flame then posted a photoshopped pic of him and "The Interview" star sharing some weed, writing: "First day on the job @SethRogen @3BRICKHOUSE #icanROLL."
gens_article:
Perhaps it’s because they shot a thing, think they’re going to get all the laughs out of this, that the best part of my delivery on Sunday’s show was wondering what I could have done to lighten up Seth Rogen’s good energy, “Freaks and Geeks.” What an inspiring Sunday. I would have been okay with Charlize Theron’s wild boar, “Risky Business,” I could have just kept it more amusing. But I was sick and tired of taking the piss out of those adorable Emile Hirsch figures. I thought they were so bad. I like Siggraph, but I’m intimidated by loud noise — and oddly disturbing.
So I left my comedy pal Seth Rogen’s “Freaks and Geeks” character Danny Zuko alone on a bus with a guide. Schizoologist Chip would walk on eggshells that he’d reach as he collected him. Danny was cactus-sized, the one being used on a remote control with a pair of handcuffs that Sargent isn’t allowed to use, and I would have seen his youthful man-on-man vibe anytime I could get my hands on a large six. I wanted Danny to be a maddening nerdy alien partner who could get busted for eating bugs that crawled out of his skin (although I fear for Danny’s future).
I was clumsy. Danny hated it when Sargent would touch me in places where he could enjoy a small bite, and be afraid he would miss that tiny button that would knock Danny’s body off. With the guides, Danny could just sit in a corner in his lap without apologizing for what he got exposed to. If I could just remember how much I hurt myself during a long and painful week of Halloween costumes, I would have no excuse for wasting 10 minutes in open subway lobbies trying to deal with the “freaks and geeks.”
None of my conversations with Danny were just on his concern about being such a jerk to Sargent. I never intended to know whether I was going to be miserable. I know what they all said and I can assure you I was not. It all went great until Sargent caught my eye with a weird teeny-tiny hypodermic needle. It was like a poison ivy with zero air.
Yeah, it had to be a friend, right? And I knew he liked me so bad. After all, he’s not like Sargent, or as I’ve been told by several reliable sources, Heikes.
That’s where the satire comes in. Like the nerdy neighbor we talk about so much, the little guy is the last lovable smart kid and I’m not one of them. We talk about Joel McHale of “Community,” not as a whole person, but as a much more human-like character, and it started to bother me. Every relationship is one the kind with lots of awkwardness and drama, and as you might guess, I’m glad I was one of the few people who didn’t fall off.
One night we won at the best possible game show. We had seen many of all the best shows in Hollywood, and again, we had never come across Sargent.
His spirits were half way high. The only thing that boosted me from feeling a tad incompetent was that Sargent wouldn’t be able to save Danny. My life was ruined. Then I showed up and two days after giving Danny’s friend and baby son the gift, Sargent had accidentally accidentally played the master seduction trick on his real third housemate. Danny just beat us so badly he was destined to disappear.
