title: Pot reportedly found on Bieber tour bus at Canadian border
text: U.S. border agents found marijuana on a bus with singer Justin Bieber's tour as it crossed into Detroit from Windsor, Canada. The Detroit Free Press reports that U.S. Customs and Border Protection spokesman Ken Hammond confirms that the bus was stopped Sunday as it attempted to enter the U.S. on the Ambassador Bridge. The singer was not on the bus at the time and performed later that night at Joe Louis Arena. Hammond says a police dog indicated the presence of drugs on the bus and that drug paraphernalia and a small amount of marijuana were found. He says the bus driver was cited and that the bus and its passengers were allowed to go.
gens_article:
Law enforcement agents at Canada's border fence stumbled on a pot-like substance in a passenger car park. The Winnipeg, Manitoba, man was discovered with a mound of marijuana in his pocket during a foot chase from a police officer, police said Wednesday.
Just prior to the police officer's siren sounding, officers seized the marijuana from the Jeep ahead of the rest of the people in the vehicle, Sgt. Ray Varesca said.
Varesca would not say how many cannabis drugs were found, but the suspect was identified as David Laufman. He was charged with simple possession of cannabis and an unrelated border law violation, police said.
The officer struck Laufman in the head with the police baton and threw him from the car. A few minutes later, investigators discovered 6,800 grams of marijuana in his backpack.
"Apparently, (Law enforcement) did not do the careful searching they were used to in the past," Varesca said.
Laufman was taken to the Winnipeg police station, where he was eventually charged with simple possession of cannabis, a federal offence. However, the incident, with multiple highways involved, raised questions about whether there is evidence that is being used by authorities to make illegal drugs in Canada.
The investigation into police snoops at Canada's border increased during the weekend. Before off-duty police officers could take part in any area activities they were allowed to do, provincial police in Winnipeg say they learned about a variety of pot-related incidents throughout the weekend and rushed to the border fence.
"Obviously we know that there's a lot of activity here. We'd like to have all the parties in one place," said Mark Kauer, chair of the traffic management and border patrol unit for Winnipeg, whose main concern is children.
Kauer said the restrictions have caused minor, accidental mishaps.
"Overall, we see little business this weekend," he said. "Obviously this is obviously the busiest traffic (in Canada) in the last couple of weeks, so it's difficult to say where all that is coming from."
Varesca said he wasn't aware of how many people would have to be taken off the scene of an incident like this but noted the fact that the location of the drug pinged the city makes it more likely to capture young people.
"Maybe there are some people out there who may want to steal, and maybe there are kids who will grab it and have to get off," he said.

title: 181 vie for license to dispense medical marijuana in Massachusetts
text: State health officials have released a list of 181 applications they received from groups hoping to open medical marijuana dispensaries. The applicants will be competing for a maximum of 35 licenses allowed under a voter-approved law that makes marijuana available to patients with certain medical conditions. The list released on Friday by the Department of Public Health includes the preferred county in which the applicant hopes to operate. Middlesex had the most applicants with 47, followed by 21 in Suffolk County, 19 in Plymouth County and 14 in Worcester County. Applicants are not required to name a specific city or town in the first phase of a two-part application process. Some groups submitted multiple applications in one or more counties. Massachusetts hopes to begin awarding licenses by the end of the year.
gens_article:
In the state’s first medical marijuana program, police entered law enforcement centers on Cape Cod and responded to complaints that certain drugs were mixed in the pot.
Massachusetts law allows dispensing medical marijuana to addicts. The benefit is akin to allowing first responders to use their own prescription drugs to treat a psychotic or chronic condition.
“First responders like police officers can utilize the program in a much quicker way,” said State Police spokeswoman Lt. Alverne Hilburn.
During an April 2014 sweep of 80 medical marijuana centers around the state, police confiscated 164 pounds of marijuana after arresting nine people in Shannon, Mass. — 24 of whom were subject to seizure. By April of that year, 161 locations had adopted a program to dispense the substance, 28 for marijuana, and 25 had begun offering it.
More than 60 percent of drug-free sites (an estimated 100 sites total) returned marijuana within days. During the 2010-2011 period, more than 20,000 people were served.
Solitary rules are based on the Food and Drug Administration, which regulates marijuana. The states that use the program typically have their own agency, Department of Public Health. Massachusetts attorney general Martha Coakley said there was an ongoing debate over whether there should be a rule for dispensing marijuana.
State law allows doctors to prescribe marijuana to patients who are terminally ill. The state’s early-trial rejection of District of Columbia medical marijuana law that may have its hands tied by legal challenges costs Massachusetts about $1 million in legal fees.
“It will have the effect of improving the lives of the patients who are dying,” Coakley said of the law.
In 2011, the medical marijuana industry chose New Hampshire, New Jersey and Oregon as the first states to adopt laws authorizing dispensing in those states. The states all allow for dispensing by licensed physicians and pharmacists.
Under the Massachusetts system, patients would be given $2 by a doctor to allow them to be present at the dispensing; the fee would be applied to the cost of the patient’s health care.
Among other results of the program, drug dealers became widespread, arresting some 66 percent of drug-free adults in the quarter.
Dr. Dan White, a cardiologist at Longmeadow Hospital, which facilitates dispensing of marijuana, acknowledged that while “there may be some fear for the people who are going to use it, but I think we’re talking about the positives.”
Losing side effects are manageable and “we’re not losing side effects,” White said.
He said that after about two years, he hopes more people will take advantage of the program.
But many people are wary of administering the drug. Forty-six percent said they were against opening a dispensing center because they fear it might be anti-social or “excessively irresponsible.”
Cory Hanson, 43, is a member of the Drug Free Residents Section of the Massachusetts NAACP. At least 60 percent said they thought they’d be honest about their emotions or drugs in the dispensary.
“It would be disappointing, but there’s nothing wrong with helping people,” Hanson said. “People are always wondering why they’re doing this, how they’re doing it.”

title: Marijuana and pregnancy: 5 key takeaways from the new official guidelines
text: More than half of Americans support the legalization of marijuana, but questions remain about how the drug affects our health. Those questions are especially important for one group: pregnant women. Marijuana use during pregnancy is becoming more common , despite the lack of clarity about its possible effects. But today (Aug. 27), the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) released its first-ever guidelines on marijuana use for pregnant and breast-feeding women. The new recommendations are based on an analysis of the existing research on how marijuana affects pregnancy, breast-feeding and childhood development, and they touch on a range of questions that expectant parents might have. [ 7 Ways Pregnant Women Affect Babies ] Here are the most important takeaways from the report. Don't use marijuana, in any form, during pregnancy. The AAP report concludes that completely avoiding marijuana use during pregnancy is best. That's in part because THC , or tetrahydrocannabinol the compound responsible for marijuana's psychoactive effects can cross the placenta. Several long-term studies have found relationships between marijuana use by pregnant women and slightly shorter gestational periods and lower birth weights, according to the report. Other studies looking at newborns have found that babies who were exposed to marijuana in utero had some other irregularities compared with other babies, such as unusual sleep patterns. Ultimately, based on the available evidence, the AAP decided to recommend against the use of marijuana during pregnancy, said Dr. Seth Ammerman, a pediatrics professor at Stanford University and a co-author of the AAP report. Dr. Torri Metz, a high-risk obstetrician at University of Utah Health, who wasn't involved with the report, said this stance from pediatricians falls in line with what experts in other medical specialties, such as obstetrics and gynecology, have concluded. "This is not a paradigm shift but something we should continue to emphasize," Metz told Live Science. Don't use marijuana while breast-feeding. Breast-feeding moms should avoid marijuana use, because THC, along with some other potentially psychoactive compounds in pot, gets into breast milk, Ammerman told Live Science. In fact, a new study published alongside the report in the journal Pediatrics looked at breast milk from 50 women who used marijuana and found THC in 63 percent of the samples up to six days after they reported using the drug. Other cannabinoids, such as cannabidiol (CBD), showed up in just 5 percent of the samples. More on this... The 11 strangest pregnancy trends Blossoming body: 8 odd changes that happen during pregnancy 18 ways pregnancy may change your body forever Because other research found that these compounds could impact fetal development, it's possible that they could also affect a breast-feeding child, the researchers noted. But that specific link hasn't been explored, and breast-feeding is the still recommended option for a child's milk, Ammerman said. "The goal is to encourage breast-feeding," he said, "but if you're breast-feeding and using marijuana, you should cut down or stop" marijuana use. There's no research showing that marijuana helps to treat morning sickness. The new report acknowledges that some pregnant women may use marijuana because they've heard that it eases morning sickness. But "there are no research studies that say marijuana is effective for nausea in pregnancy," Metz told Live Science. If nausea during pregnancy is a problem, there are several treatments approved for use , including vitamin B6 and doxylamine, she added. Doctors who treat sexually active women should talk to them about drug use. Accidental pregnancies happen, and if someone is using drugs in the weeks before they know they're pregnant, that could cause problems for a fetus in its most critical stages, Ammerman said. "One of the hopes of our recommendations is that pediatricians will take a more proactive role in counseling their patients who are sexually active about these issues, because it is really important," he said. In addition to discussing these recommendations with patients, doctors should be careful to avoid judging women regarding drug use, Ammerman added. There are still a lot of questions that need be answered. Despite the publication of the guidelines, there's still a lot of research that needs to be done. For example, researchers have worked primarily with marijuana compounds, like THC and CBD, that people hear about most, but there are dozens more that deserve studies, Ammerman said. There's also a lot of room for research on what, if any, complications marijuana can cause for pregnant women themselves, Metz noted. And researching marijuana's impact on child development can also be difficult. It's unethical to give marijuana to pregnant individuals, so researchers mostly rely on data from parents who report using the drug. What's more, researchers have to account for the different ways pot is used, and decipher the dose concentrations, which are changing THC concentrations in marijuana increased from about 4 percent in the 1990s to about 12 percent in 2014. And, of course, the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration still classifies marijuana as a Schedule I drug, which puts up a lot of barriers for researchers, Ammerman said.
gens_article:
By Leslie Nemo
You may think you have heard everything from the new guideline from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on marijuana to abortion to universal coverage of certain birth-related medical conditions, but you're soon on the Internet. With nearly 4 million new prescriptions for marijuana each month, the feds have laid out six major aspects of its flagship effort, hoping to better address chronic pain and stress associated with marijuana use.
The new guidelines are a timely advance for any public health concern. Much of what was previously known about the dangers of marijuana is now in the final words of guidance and already discussed on film and television, scripted shows and other public health news outlets.
In the midst of much upheaval and uncertainty, the new guidelines fully outline several important steps to combat the growing array of strains of marijuana, including a focus on avoiding the fragility of the ingredients.
The new guidance on medical marijuana states that there is "no possibility of drug-impaired use" as long as the ingredient is already at a ready-to-use level. This means, as the experts remind, if your doctor expects you to be socially conscious and not ever use a substance that comes with significant medical benefits, its source is the compound that has been studied in research before.
The current scientific standard has been broken, and the new guidelines create a new definition of potency and the possible human consequences for not sharing that information. In essence, these new regulations are governing a growing number of popular drugs, including marijuana, as well as some more traditional sources of health care spending that have been mostly exempt from regulation.
According to most experts, it's the doctors who should start a clinical trial of marijuana to see whether it's safe or dangerous to use. Well, out of the 1,840 med-school students that were certified by the FDA to use pot, only half of them had ever seen a physician, according to the experts. They were only given two factors: the dosage that gave them THC, and the device that made them stay up all night.
The Congressional Cannabis Caucus (Caucus) is calling for more access to medical marijuana, encouraging lawmakers to move the U.S. Congress up the path to legal medical marijuana. Members of the House of Representatives are already working together on a bill, SB314, moving the FDA past the 1966 committee meetings and into a committee meeting, not the currently proposed 2012 committee meeting.
"[Separate cannabis labelling] is one of the best parts of the bill." Rep. John B. King, R-OK, told Politico in June. "We all hope that we can reach that 2012 committee meeting and repeal some of the antiquated medical-recommendation language. But there's no way we can do that without giving up this longstanding tradition of medical work, which has been the medicine for 60 percent of Americans."
Brought to light by mid-August, an enormous portion of the public health debate is centered around legalization, and in 2013, the FDA first announced its intention to hold public discussions on whether adults can use marijuana. In response, during August 2015, a wide range of experts appeared before Congress, including: Dr. Byron Isenberg, director of the Center for Cannabis Research at Colorado State University; Dr. Robert LaPorter, a professor at the University of Colorado School of Medicine and a leading spokesperson for the American Cancer Society; Dr. Reuben Moran, president of the American Society of Nephrology; and Dr. Norma Elice, a researcher at the Karolinska Institute at Stockholm.
But researchers have warned that while legalization can have positive impacts, it could violate constitutional protections for patients against the use of marijuana with opioid painkillers, opiates and other potentially addictive drugs.
Nemo writes about medical marijuana activism online. You can reach her by email at leslie.nemo@aol.com.

title: Florida doctor sells cannabis-infused ice cream
text: Cannabis-infused ice cream helps patients by doctor's orders Florida doctor swears by products with CBD extract for his patients which has soothing effects and helps with pain, anxiety and inflammation. A doctor in Florida has taken an unconventional approach to help his patientsmanage pain: ice cream cannabis-infused ice cream, to be exact. Ashok Khanna, an internal medicine physician at the Florida Primary Care Center in Winter Garden, has recently started to sell ice cream that contains CBD one of the many chemical compounds found in the cannabis plant. CBD is not psychoactive, unlike THC, another chemical compound or cannabinoid found in marijuana. This means patients who eat the ice cream will not become high, XXX reports. CBD iswidelyavailable across the U.S., though some states require a prescription to use the oil for medicinal purposes. CBD has soothing effects.The oil has been used to treat patients with anxiety and depression, according to Healthline . Retired NFL players have also used it as a way to alleviate pain, Mens Health reported . In June, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug derived from marijuana to treat epilepsy. The ice cream made by the Florida-based Heavenly Hash Creamery has also been beneficial for those battling cancer, helping with inflammation and pain, according to XXX. "It makes sense to give them something that'll make them feel better, Khanna told the news station of his decision to sell the ice cream.
gens_article:
A Florida pharmacist in desperate need of more clear medical options is selling a drug for dozens of dollars a pop that leaves no sense of smell.
So would-be quackery seekers shot up when The Dr. Phil Show aired the real-life story of a pharmacist who over-prescribed a cocktail of plant drugs that directly caused a heart attack.
Dr. Hannah Kigal, a licensed physician in Florida from Ventura County, tells the Atlanta Journal-Constitution that a synthetic stimulant used in his practice is the most common herb she has ever grown.
“Ventura County has historically gotten an abundance of crazy drugs, mostly medical maladies that are being prescribed to people to get them over, that are getting tired, and not being properly administered,” Kigal said.
But this is not an experiment — according to Kigal, the doctor filled the prescription on a bad note — and that’s bad for doctors.
“People who use the drug don’t have to take a hit and its good,” Kigal explained. “For many people, it’s a no-no if they live right in the medical community.”
Other physicians have even taken Kigal’s observations to heart and urged him to start using plant-based medications for self-help.
“When they tell you that the FDA is against this, they remind you that they’re completely controlled by the FDA,” revealed Dr. Douglas Cusack, a clinical associate of Pathology and Molecular Medicine at Memorial Hermann Hermann Hospital in Hermann, Texas.
Cusack told FoxNews.com that it was only one medication prescribed in the bag, and that he wouldn’t make any recommendations to patients on the drug unless his physicians advised him.
“I would not fill a prescription for any medication,” Cusack told FoxNews.com. “It’s legal under the law. This is a narcotic. If you take an over-the-counter drug, don’t be afraid to stop if you run into troubles.”
The doctor mentioned the illegal drug fentanyl — which involves consuming a high of about 100 times a milligram of fentanyl — but said it’s been picked up more than once by law enforcement.
Kigal, for one, believes the medication isn’t good for the body.
“Generally, people have over-the-counter and non-prescription medications or they just get a more level of understanding,” said Kigal. “However, I think the same is true for herbs and I think it’s fair to say that some people have over-the-counter or non-prescription, still not being fully prescription-ed.”
Kigal claimed her practice does not have an FDA approval process, but she did highlight a waiting period before dispensing the new medication. However, Kigal insisted she doesn’t mind on the ongoing health scares that have prevented her from dispensing the medication, and also dealt with the pain of “being over-doctor.”
“I’m not concerned about the growing problem of over-the-counter medicine,” Kigal told FoxNews.com. “I’m concerned about patients being caught up in these traumas and getting burned out.”

title: Marijuana use by adults tied to few physical health problems
text: Other than being at an increased risk of gum disease, people who smoked marijuana for up to 20 years during adulthood were generally as healthy as people who didn't light up, according to a new study. The same researchers had previously found that marijuana users were at higher risk of cognitive decline and descent into lower social and economic strata, but the new study suggests the same isn't true for physical health. "The only measures that seemed to indicate any really serious health problem was periodontal disease," said senior author Terrie Moffitt, of Duke University in Durham, North Carolina. In periodontal disease, the gums around the teeth become inflamed, according to the National Institutes of Health. The gums pull away from the teeth, creating pockets that can become infected. Left untreated, periodontitis can lead to loss of teeth. For the new study, the researchers studied 1,037 people born in New Zealand in 1972 and 1973. Participants were tracked from age 3 to age 38. Overall, about 65 percent reported using marijuana at some point after age 18, according to the results in JAMA Psychiatry. The researchers did not find a link between marijuana use in adulthood and poor physical health for a number of conditions, including lung function, systemic inflammation, metabolic health, blood pressure and body mass index (BMI), which is a measure of weight in relation to height. After adjusting for a number of factors like tobacco use, the researchers did find that marijuana use throughout adulthood was tied to gum disease toward the end of the study period. Moffitt told Reuters Health that the connection between marijuana use and the oral condition is likely explained by people putting lit objects close to their gums. "Anything you smoke heats up your gums and causes inflammation and inflammation is bad for your teeth," she said. For comparison, the researchers also looked at whether tobacco was tied to any poor physical health outcomes. They found it was tied to a number of poor health outcomes like inflammation, gum disease, cholesterol, lung function and blood sugar. Cannabis "is not a really big public health problem right now whether it causes mental health problems, downward social mobility and physical ailments because not many people are using it compared to tobacco and alcohol," said Moffitt. "If the proportion of people who are likely to use cannabis were to increase, many problems associated with it would naturally increase as well," she said.
gens_article:
Medical marijuana users who are not pregnant or teenagers are less likely to have suicidal or unstable behavior such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder, according to new research published online this week in JAMA Psychiatry.
People who smoke marijuana regularly report fewer psychoses and social disorder reactions than those who are addicted to the drug. This is true even after controlling for medical conditions.
The researchers explained in the same context that marijuana had been misclassified as a prescription drug or illegal by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration in the early 1980s.
Previous research suggested that marijuana and its addictive components might help people cope with health problems. But after the writing of a heart-attack study, newly published health information to the test subjects suggested that marijuana consumption might be part of the primary cause of the phenomenon, said Jonathan Dee, an assistant professor at Columbia University’s Richard Parsons School of Public Health who co-authored the study.
“While nicotine and other addictive substances did increase depressive symptoms, marijuana use was still the dominant or contributory factor of high depressive symptoms among young people who were pot smokers and high opioid users,” Dee said in a statement.
“This finding demonstrates that use of marijuana by adolescent marijuana users was associated with a higher mental health risk than marijuana use by adult users,” Dee said.
The researchers compared marijuana users in several states who had completed the Survey on Drug Use and Health conducted by the National Institute on Drug Abuse. They found that marijuana use among single adults was comparable with the prevalence of schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and bipolar disorder among adolescents.
“This article shows marijuana use in adolescents is linked to significant behavioral changes that are often delayed by medical conditions,” Dee and his colleagues wrote.
The researchers said they believe that mental illness is a huge problem in young people and recommend that marijuana users discuss with their physicians their risks and risks for their health.
“Marijuana use may be a medical problem at the low rate of one of many forms of control over the drug, particularly among the state level,” Dee said.
The researchers said the prevalence of psychosis in young people in their studies was only modest and that this “no doubt stems from the unfulfilled demand of doctors as a home for the medication of cannabis.”
“Since new research by leading researchers from around the world showed that marijuana use changes symptoms and harms of psychosis, it’s important to realize that being a doctor or mental health professional may be a gateway to this growing problem,” Dee said.
The data base of the research is not complete. Details of the data can be found at www.jama.com/medical-marijuana/methics/.
